text.name: sys_description
text.text: The CD-i, Compact Disc Interactive, is a video game console and multimedia player designed by Philips, Sony and Matsushita in 1991. It embeds a 16-bit processor at 15.5 Mhz, 1.5 MB of RAM, displays 384x280 at 768x560 pixels in 32768 colors and an 8-channel sound card. Its CD drive is capable of reading 650 MB media or 75 minutes of video at 2x speed, well above the capacity of a cartridge. Its failure was caused by a high player price, low quality games, and the inability to play full screen videos in its basic version without an very expensive MPEG module.
